article.headline: Pittsburgh 83, Albany 54
article.story: PITTSBURGH (AP) -- The extra work Carl Krauser spent on his jump shot paid off for Pittsburgh. Krauser scored 16 of his career-high 22 points in the second half to help No. 22 Pittsburgh beat Albany 83-54 Friday night. Krauser shot 8-for-12 from the field and accounted for six of Pitt's 14 3-pointers. He scored at least 20 points for the third time in four games. "I felt good, particularly in the second half," Krauser said. "I worked on my jump shot (Thursday) night at practice and earlier today at the shootaround and the ball was going in for me." Julius Page scored 16 points, Antonio Graves added 11 and Chris Taft 10 for Pitt (4-0), which won its 25th straight home game, the fourth-longest streak in Division I. Levi Levine scored 16 points for Albany (0-2). Krauser's six 3s were two short of the individual team record, and the Panthers came within two 3-pointers of the overall team mark. The Panthers took advantage of Albany's zone by shooting 9-for-13 from beyond the arc in the second half. Pitt shot 70.4 percent in the second half, compared to 35.5 percent in the first. "We made some adjustments at the half and got more ball movement. That was the main thing," Pitt coach Jamie Dixon said. Pitt led by five points, 32-27, at the half, and by six with 15 minutes remaining before putting the game away with a 13-0 run. Krauser's 3-pointer with 10:15 left gave Pitt a 59-39 lead. Krauser was surprised that Albany never switched from its zone defense. "I didn't think they would play us like that," he said. "I thought we'd see man-to-man and have them force us to make turnovers. But it forced us to make our shots and we did in the second half." Albany, coming off a 7-21 season and competing in its fifth season at Division I, gave the Panthers fits for the first 25 minutes. Page and Krauser made 3-pointers to put Pitt ahead 17-9, but Levine converted two three-point plays, cutting the deficit to 22-20 with 9:13 left in the half. But Albany went almost six minutes before scoring its next basket, allowing the Panthers to increase their lead to nine points. Taft got the run started with a dunk, and Graves hit a 3-pointer. Albany closed within 32-27 on Jon Iati's basket in the final minute of the half. "For 20 minutes, we forced a very good basketball team to play into our hands," Albany coach Will Brown said. "In the second half, they made just about every shot they took. You saw the talent difference in the second half." Albany's Jamar Wilson, who averaged 18.9 points as a freshman and was the America East Conference's rookie of the year, missed his second consecutive game with a fractured patella in his right knee.
